questions.question: What is meant by 'low altitude windshear'?
options: Turbulence at or below FL50
A sudden change in wind direction at any altitude below 2000 ft
A sudden change in wind velocity on the runway, final approach or in the climb-out
An unexpected crosswind when the aeroplane is on the runway
questions.solution: A sudden change in wind velocity on the runway, final approach or in the climb-out

questions.question: Vertical windshear is defined as:
options: a change in wind velocity with height
a change in wind speed with an increase in altitude
a change in wind direction, contrary to that expected, with an increase in altitude
a rapid change in speed of an ascending current of air
questions.solution: a change in wind velocity with height

questions.question: Horizontal windshear is defined as:
options: a change in wind direction with a change in horizontal distance
a change in wind force over a defined area
a change of wind velocity with horizontal distance
any change in speed of a wind that is blowing horizontally
questions.solution: a change of wind velocity with horizontal distance

questions.question: What would you expect to happen in an 'up and down draught' windshear?
options: The wind velocity to vary with both altitude and horizontal displacement from a datum
Initially an updraught causing the aeroplane to rise uncontrollably, and subsequently a downdraught causing uncontrolled descent
Encountering alternately rising and descending air currents in the vicinity of large cloud formations
Vertical excursions in horizontal flight

questions.question: With what met phenomena is windshear most associated?
options: Thunderstorms
Passage of a warm front
Tropical revolving storms
Standing mountain waves

questions.question: Apart from the answer to Q5, windshear can also be found in the vicinity of hills and structures. Where particularly would windshear in this instance be found?
options: Upwind and above the hills or structures
In the lee of hills and structures but well above the ground
Downwind of hills and structures from ground level upwards
On the seaward side of hills and structures where no other obstructions are found
questions.solution: Downwind of hills and structures from ground level upwards

questions.question: If, during an approach to land you encounter an abrupt decrease in wind speed or a shift to a tail wind the aircraft will........ and you should...........
options: suffer a loss of lift / apply power
increase speed due to reduced drag / lift the nose
yaw to starboard / apply right rudder
suffer an energy gain / reduce power and lower the nose
questions.solution: suffer a loss of lift / apply power

questions.question: Shortly after take-off the attitude of the aeroplane suffers an abrupt pitch-up and IAS rapidly decreases followed quickly by a decrease in altitude. Engine indications are normal. You should suspect what, and what should you do?
options: Marked temperature drop; apply full power
Loss of headwind or an increase in tailwind; apply full power
Incipient engine failure (ignore instruments); lower the nose to gain airspeed
Local clear air turbulence; reduce speed to VRA and ride it out
questions.solution: Loss of headwind or an increase in tailwind; apply full power

questions.question: On an ILS final approach, you notice that the sky is darkening, visibility is reducing and turbulence is increasing. At the same time you encounter an energy gain situation causing you to 'balloon' above the glide path. What should you do?
options: Suspect windshear and correct power and attitude to regain the glide path
Suspect that you have passed through the top of the turbulence layer and that the wind is no longer geostrophic, so corrections to power and attitude are required
Suspect microburst activity and pre-empt the inevitable energy loss situation by leaving power and attitude settings as before and then correct once clear of the microburst
Suspect microburst activity, apply full power, climb as per the missed approach procedure and go around for a further approach after the microburst has cleared the approach area
questions.solution: Suspect microburst activity, apply full power, climb as per the missed approach procedure and go around for a further approach after the microburst has cleared the approach area

questions.question:
With which of the following should you be aware of the possibility of microburst activity?
1. Thunderstorms
2. Cumulonimbus clouds
3. Gust front activity (rising dust clouds)
4. Unexpected windshear
5. Sudden rain squalls
6. Virga
options: All the above
2, 4 and 5
2, 5 and 6
